issue.title: Reading training and inference rasters from STAC item list: input as json

milestone.title: Operational data pipeline
milestone.description: Iplement this workflow : Pre-processing new images ->storing COGs in the datacube -> run inference service in a hybrid Kubernetes (Rancher on AWS) and HPC (gpsc3) infrastructure

repository.name: geo-deep-learning
repository.description: Deep learning applied to georeferenced datasets

issue.body:
Soon, GDL will internally be used to read images from an S3 bucket, using STAC items and Franklin's API to submit requests based on spatial, temporal or other filters from metadata. 

GDL's readers should therefore transition from csv as input (#221) to a json containing a list of STAC items (as json). Here's an example of a response from a request passed to Franklin that could directly be used by GDL in the future:
`{
    "type": "FeatureCollection",
    "context":
    {
        "returned": 1,
        "matched": 1
    },
    "features":
    [
        {
            "id": "QC15_052686187030_01_QuickBird2",
            "stac_version": "1.0.0-beta.2",
            "stac_extensions":
            [
                "https://stac-extensions.github.io/projection/v1.0.0/schema.json"
            ],
            "type": "Feature",
            "geometry":
            {
                "type": "Polygon",
                "coordinates":
                ...
    ],
    [ (2nd STAC item)
    ],
    [ (3rd STAC item)
    ],
    "links":
    [],
    "stac_version": "1.0.0"
}`

Here are 5 examples of STAC Items for IA-Ready images as served by Franklin's API:
https://datacube-stage.services.geo.ca/api/collections/worldview-3-ortho-pansharp/items/QC22_055128844110_01_WV3
https://datacube-stage.services.geo.ca/api/collections/worldview-4-ortho-pansharp/items/MB8_059380728010_01_P001_WV4
https://datacube-stage.services.geo.ca/api/collections/worldview-2-ortho-pansharp/items/VancouverP003_054230029070_01_P003_WV2
https://datacube-stage.services.geo.ca/api/collections/geoeye-1-ortho-pansharp/items/AB13_059294491080_01_GeoEye1
https://datacube-stage.services.geo.ca/api/collections/quickbird-2-ortho-pansharp/items/QC15_052686187030_01_QuickBird2

An issue remains: how to link the ground truth to this list? A separate json? This needs further analysis.

issue.title: Reading single-band rasters: unified approach with multiband reader

milestone.title: Operational data pipeline
milestone.description: Iplement this workflow : Pre-processing new images ->storing COGs in the datacube -> run inference service in a hybrid Kubernetes (Rancher on AWS) and HPC (gpsc3) infrastructure

repository.name: geo-deep-learning
repository.description: Deep learning applied to georeferenced datasets

issue.body:
As operationalization approaches, inference.py will need to read and concatenate single band rasters rather than [multiband only](https://github.com/NRCan/geo-deep-learning/blob/develop/inference.py#L120). This implies extending [sample_creation.py](https://github.com/NRCan/geo-deep-learning/blob/develop/sample_creation.py)'s use to inference.py and possibly merging with [images_to_samples.py](https://github.com/NRCan/geo-deep-learning/blob/develop/images_to_samples.py) (soon to become data_to_tiles.py --> #215 ). 

This issue is closely related to #221 and #222. A future reading utility will have to manage a list of rasters as input with variable configration (some may be multiband, others will be single-band, maybe even for a same training dataset). This utility will then be available for tiling as well as inference.

body:
Rethinking this issue, I think CSVs could still be useful as an input to GDL's tiling / inference since [it's a format everyone and their grandmother know and GDL isn't using it to store data, just to reference it](https://towardsdatascience.com/stop-using-csvs-for-storage-here-are-the-top-5-alternatives-e3a7c9018de0). What I'd suggest for the future of GDL, is expect a minimal csv with three columns for training and one column for inference:

## minimal training's csv columns
| imagery path | vector ground truth path  | dataset |
| ----------- | --- | --------------- |
| my_dir/my_geoimagery1.tif | my_dir/my_geogt1.gpkg | trn |
| my_dir/my_geoimagery2.tif | my_dir/my_geogt2.gpkg | tst |
| ... | ... | ... |

## minimal inference csv columns
| imagery path |
| ----------- | 
| my_dir/my_newgeoimagery1.tif |
| my_dir/my_newgeoimagery2.tif |
| ... |

Therefore, for training, [we'd remove the 2nd column "meta"](https://github.com/NRCan/geo-deep-learning/blob/develop/utils/utils.py#L415), used to reference metadata to include as training data. This relates to a feature that we removed in #227 . We could also discuss the relevance of keeping the 4th column "attribute_name" (aka attribute field). The natural (and currently implemented) place to define an attribute name and value to use to filter all ground truth data [is in the dataset config](https://github.com/NRCan/geo-deep-learning/blob/develop/config/dataset/test_ci_segmentation_binary.yaml#L16). However, if we still think a user might need to reference an attribute field and values on a per-file basis, the csv's 4th and 5th columns could be dedicated to optionally setting per-file attribute fields and values if they differ from one file to the other. If these columns are not empty, the dataset config would be overridden by these values and the tiling process would rely on the per-file values, not the dataset-wide ones.

Last thing, for inference, if a ground truth file is specified in an optional 2nd column, then inference could automatically perform metric evaluation. In previous homemade tests, I also used an extra column to set a name for the aoi in each row. This helps make a more human readable report of evaluation/benchmark, for example. This should be discussed

Here's a before/after outlook of our training / inference csv *with all optional columns*

## Current input csv columns
| imagery path | metdata path | vector ground truth path  | attribute name | dataset |
| ----------- | --- | --------------- | --------------- | --------------- |
| my_dir/my_geoimagery1.tif | my_metadata1.tif | my_dir/my_geogt1.gpkg | QuatreClasses | trn |
| my_dir/my_geoimagery2.tif | my_metadata2.tif | my_dir/my_geogt2.gpkg | QuatreClasses | tst |
| ... | ... | ... | ... | ... |

## Proposed input csv columns
| imagery path | vector ground truth path  | dataset | attribute field | attribute values | AOI name (for benchmarking purposes)
| ----------- | --- | --------------- | --------------- | --------------- | --------------- |
| my_dir/my_geoimagery1.tif | my_dir/my_geogt1.gpkg | trn | QuatreClasses | 1,2,3 | Moncton, NB
| my_dir/my_geoimagery2.tif | my_dir/my_geogt2.gpkg | tst | CinqClasses | 1,2,3 | Vancouver, BC
| ... | ... | ... | ... | ... | ... |
french or English the attribute field?

> french or English the attribute field?

This is just an example. The "attribute field" column (and all other columns actually) would accept any utf-8 character, and would be case-sensitive.

I think it's a fair assumption to "define an attribute name and value to use to filter all ground truth data [in the dataset config](https://github.com/NRCan/geo-deep-learning/blob/develop/config/dataset/test_ci_segmentation_binary.yaml#L16)". W would then remove the `attribute field` and the `attribute values` from the csv.

issue.title: Update (remove unused columns, add aoi_id, reorganize columns) in input csv for tiling/sampling and inference

repository.name: geo-deep-learning
repository.description: Deep learning applied to georeferenced datasets

issue.body:
in input csv:
- "metadata" and "attribute_name" columns are removed (2nd and 4th column)
- ground truth column becomes 2nd column (not 3th)
- dataset split ("trn" or "tst") becomes 3rd column (not 5th)
- A last column (4th) is added for an "aoi id". This last information is not currently used, but could be to print a detailed report of tiling, training and evaluation, or for easier debugging.

Also in this PR:
- update test data for binary segmentation to smaller clipped tiles (under 100 Ko rather than 1Mb);
- remove data in data/ (use only data in tests/data/...
- default tiling to 32x32 chips for this smaller dataset;
- add ValueError if is train or val dataloader is empty

For more info on original suggested solution (slightly modified after discussion), see: https://github.com/NRCan/geo-deep-learning/issues/221#issuecomment-1121310523
fixes #221

rename.from: Deprecation: csv as input for sampling and inference
rename.to: Csv as input for sampling and inference: format needs update
